Miraculous path led player to NCAA Festival

Heart attack, then a miracle for volleyball player

Miraculous path led player to NCAA Festival

Michael Grant, mgrant@courier-journal.com 3:22 p.m. EST December 4, 2014

University of New Haven senior Ashley Dalton (middle) runs through drills with the rest of her team while practicing for the NCAA Volleyball Tournament at Bellarmine University's Knights Hall. Wednesday Dec. 3, 2014. (By William DeShazer, Special to the C-J)(Photo: William DeShazer)

4 CONNECTTWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Ashley Dalton's University of New Haven teammates and volleyball coach describe her as a living miracle.

Four months ago, she was clinically dead. The senior went into cardiac arrest - her heart stopped. Now, not only is Dalton alive and well but she starts for New Haven which has reached the NCAA Division II tournament quarterfinals.

The Chargers will play Arkansas - Fort Smith on Thursday night at Bellarmine University's Knights Hall as part of the NCAA Division II National Championships Fall Festival.

COURIER-JOURNAL

Louisville, Bellarmine welcome 1,100 athletes for NCAA Division II Festival

"The heart of a champion has been our team theme since this happened," the married 24 year-old said. "I know it's a miracle and I know that the team knows that it's a miracle."

Dalton has no recollection of what happened on Aug. 30.

Her last memory of that day? Her husband taking the car for an oil change. That's it. She doesn't remember participating in a team-building exercise. She doesn't recall falling down. She certainly doesn't remember being in a medically-induced coma for 48 hours.

Her first indication that something was wrong was when she woke up in a Hartford hospital and saw her mother who lives in Montana in the room. She was confused and asked for her husband Tony who was sitting next to her.

COURIER-JOURNAL

Division II athletes on local outreach mission

Dalton was shocked to learn that she had a heart condition. But possibly not as shocked as her teammates who saw her collapse.

"I felt terrified," senior Hayley Wilson said. "I was praying that she was OK."

On Aug. 30, coach Robin Salters took her team to an off-campus facility called Empower which bills itself as a "leadership sports and adventure center." The Chargers did a relay race and Dalton went first since she's one of the fastest members of the team. Dalton ran up an incline and turned around to sprint back.

That's when Salters saw a "confused" look on Dalton's face and the senior collapsed.

"She was stiff and gasping for breath," the coach said. "There was a glazed look in her eyes. She started to turn blue. It was incredibly frightening. It was the scariest thing I've ever seen in my life."

Fortunately, there happened to be a nurse and an EMT worker at the facility. 911 was called. CPR was administered. But Dalton's pulse was fading and at one point her heart stopped. An automated external defibrillator was used to restart her heart.

When Dalton regained consciousness days later, the first person she saw was her mom.

"They broke it to me slowly," she said. "They told me I had a heart episode. They were trying to be gentle. But it wasn't clicking because I had no idea I had a heart problem. It came out of the blue."

Dalton was diagnosed with Long QT Syndrome. According to the Mayo Clinic website, LQTS is a heart rhythm disorder that can potentially cause fast, chaotic heartbeats. It can lead to sudden death.

Amazingly, Dalton did not suffer any brain or physical damage. An implantable defibrillator was placed in the left side of her chest. A doctor told Dalton that her volleyball career was over.

But Dalton over the next few months, she slowly increased her physical activity. She started with ballet – something she had done for nine years as a child. Dalton eventually got to the point in late October that the doctors medically cleared her to resume playing volleyball.

On Halloween night, Dalton was back for the Chargers. She appeared in one set and had a pair of digs. To celebrate her return, New Haven made it "Cardiac Awareness Night." The nurse, EMT and the rest of the first-responders who helped to save Dalton's life were invited.

"I had the first serve of the game," Dalton said. "My heart was racing. It was such a special event for me."

Her coach and teammates say she is the same. Dalton gets fatigued more quickly but she is living the life she wants. Next year, the aspiring dental hygienist will return to her home state of Montana.

"I'm not going to live in fear," she said. "I'm not going to be afraid of what could happen. I don't want anything to hold me back. There are so many things I want to do with my life."

Contact Michael Grant at (502) 582-4069, and on Twitter @MichaelGrant_CJ
